div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: COLONIAL COTTON GROWING.
div.p: The "Wall Street Journal" of New York remarks :

The position taken by the European representatives at the International Cotton Congress of Vienna, emphasizing their purpose to extend the area of cotton cultivation in all parts of the world where the fibre could be grown, is one which must make for the advantage of the cotton interests abroad as well as at home.

The ground taken was, that for climatic reasons the European cotton milling industry could not afford to stake its prosperity upon the outcome of the crop in any one country, even though it be the United States. The world's production for mill | consumption last year was nearly 20,000,000 bales, of which the United States supplied two-thirds, which grows within an area of | 700,000 square miles. This crop, the Europeans contend, is grown on too small a climatic area to be depended upon exclusively or to the extent now prevailing. Nearly 40 per cent. of the cotton grown in the United States is now gathered from the territory west of the Mississippi, and four states lying along the Gulf, on both sides of that

river, grow 65 per cent. of the total crop. | A failure to the extent of 50 per cent. of the yield in these states would probably close one-third of the cotton mills of the world. From the consumers standpoint, therefore, it is good insurance to push cultivation in other parts of the world.

>Another advantage often overlooked is that which comes to American spinners and growers from outside competition. The idea that the United States has a monopoly of cotton growing has done more harın than good to the methods of cultivation. Such a sense of advantages inevitably superinduces indifference, resulting in lack of progress. The resoluteness of the European representatives, in pushing cotton cultivation in Africa, in Asia and in colonial possessions generally, is to be commended rather than discouraged. Several American mills are already depending almost wholly upon Egyptian cotton for lack of the long staple upland which has almost ceased to be grown. The time may come when foreign grown cotton will figure much more largely in the raw material demands of our mills than it does now.. There will then be no small advantage accruing from the foresight of European consumers.

div.head: Motor Car Fatality.
div.p: The Chief Rabbi Solomon Hakim, of Safet, whom we reported to have been run over by a motor car at Cairo, has succumbed to the injuries which he received.

div.head: Police and the Press.
div.p: Tomorrow the libel actions against "Al Mokattam," "Al Shark" and "El Watan" will be tried before the Esbekieh Court for libelling an Alexandrian Police Agent and accusing him of taking bribery.

div.head: Tramway Fatality.
div.p: Yesterday, at noon, a native youth of some 12 years of age met his death by being run over by a tram in Cairo. The tram passed completely over him, mutilating him horribly, and causing instant death.

div.head: Sponges at Port-Said.
div.p: "Al-Akhbar" states that a Port-Said boatman discovered a sponge field in the neighbourhood of that port. He made arrangements with a number of Greeks, who exploited the field and realized a profit of 70,000 francs in less than three months.

div.head: Census of the Bedouins.
div.p: The Minister of War has established a special central office in Cairo and will establish branches in the provinces for the registry and counting of the Bedouins. The new.office has been put under the management of Sagh Hlinssein Effendi Raghi.

div.head: Bubonic Plague.
div.p: Two further cases of plagne are reported among those who inhabited the Hotel de la Poste, one of whom is an Italian and the other a servant. Two Greeks from a bakery in Rue Rosette have also been admitted to hospital. One new admission of a native is reported from Beba.

div.head: Sale of Poisons.
div.p: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs has communicated to the Diplomatic Agents of the powers the draft regulations for the sale of poisons to be transmitted to their respective Governments for final approval. The regulations were approved by the Internationl Commission at its sitting of 17th June last.

div.head: Cadis School
div.p: About six hundred and twenty pupils of the Azhar University and other Mohammedan theological schools have applied for admission to the new Cadis School which is to open its doors from the beginning of the next scholastic year Six hundred of the applicants desire to be admitted to the section for the training of clerks for Mehkemehs and only about twenty to the Cadi Section

div.head: How to Treat Egyptians.
div.p: An instructive and remarkable work has just been published for private circulation by a high Anglo-Egyptian official. The author is Mr. A. Mitchell-Innes, Under Secretary of State for Finance, and his essay deals with the delicate problem of how to treat the natives. It is published for private circulation, so we cannot reproduce any extracts from this work, which we understand is replete with excellent sentiments in regard to the theory of conduct to be followed in our dealings with natives.

div.head: The Australian Mail,
div.p: The Postmaster-General's Department at Melbourne has issued an invitation for tenders for the oversea mail service. A list of conditions which accompanies the invitation states that the service to be performed is the conveyance of mails between Adelaide and Naples or Brindisi or another suitable port in Southern Europe, and an approved port in the United Kingdom, by way of the Suez Canal. Sailings are to be fortnightly each way. The right of substituting another route for the Suez Canal is reserved, and the Postmaster-General may alter the port of call in Continental Europe.

div.head: Murder of an English Stoker.
div.p: The Alexandria City Police have arrested some Europeans in connection with the death of an English stoker from a merchant vessel in the harbour. A short time ago a man, was seen to stumble and fall in Abou Dardaa-street one evening, and it was found that he had been stabbed in various place. He expired from his wounds. It appears that this stoker visited an immoral establishment in the parlieus of Sisters-street. A dispute arose about the question of payment between the man and the denizens of the house, and finally some of the souteneurs belonging to the place plunged their daggers into him. The persons arrested are foreign subjects.

div.head: Alexandria Economical Houses.
div.p: Consequent to the decisions taken by the Municipality Commission regarding the construction of economical houses, which has been postponed until next autumn, and in order to re-assure those who are interesting themselves in the matter, on the 12th inst. Chevalier L. Ronci visited Chataway Bey, who assured him that the construction of houses in the Moharrem Bey district could not yet take place, in consequence of the absence of the advisers of the Alexandria Municipality, and that on their return attention will be paid to this subject. He also assured Mr. Ronci that everything would be definitely settled as soon as possible according to the agreements already come to.

div.head:
FRENCH NATIONAL FETE
CELEBRATIONS IN CAIRO.
div.p: Praise of the work of the committee which has so ably carried out the arduous task of the fourteenth of July celebrations, is general in the press and amongst the public. The praise is richly deserved, for their efforts have been crowned with the success so richly merited. The soirée de gala of "la Grande Famille" held in the Garden Theatre on Saturday evening was most excellently attended. The rôles were well sustained and any individual distinction would be rather difficult; we might, however mention Mr. Alazet's rendering of the cheerful and happygo-lucky Corporal to whom nothing came amiss. As befitted the occasion there was a yeneral demand for the "Marseillaise" which was sung by Miss Lambertini --tastefully garbed as the Republic, the chorus being taken up by the rest of the troupe grouped on the stage with the tricolour in their midst, and the whole of the audience, who rose from their seats unanimously.

On Sunday morning the usual visits were exchanged, and a considerable amount of bunting was displayed in the principal quarfers ; a very large number of Hellenic flags were in evidence and the French nation should be proud to see what a general Hesire there was on all hands to brighten up the city on their festival. Some of our contemporaries even go so far as to describe the fourteenth of July as an International Fête.

It is many years since a finer sight has beer seen than that of the Esbekieh Gardens wher thrown open to the public on Sunday evening and it wanted only the liberal attendance o the admiring crowds to complete the gratifying success attending the function. It would be hard to estimate the number present, but from the moment of the opening of the gates unti an early hour on Monday morning, a steady stream of visitors thronged the provisiona pathway opened from the central gate opposite the Continental to the pavilion in the centre on the site of the old lake, which was rendered almost as bright as day by the hanging lanterns on both sides.

At the entrance, our old friend, the Arc de Triomph, which has officiated at so many fourteenths of July, Khedivial and Turkish Anniversaries, etc. was brilliantly lighted and looked quite youthful under the kind shield o night.

The reception pavilion was graced by another arch, simply, but well ornamented with jets, and all the side avehues were bordered with lanterns ; the sight was extrernely effective, and altogether the scene of the continnally moving crowds. formed a veritable picture which will be remembered with pleasure by all who were present, while the well-chosen programmes rendered by the deservedly popular band of the Inuiskilling Fusiliers under their able conductor, Mr. Watson Ramsey, and the Egyptian Cavalry Banil added greatly to the enjoyment of the evening.

The French Minister and Mr. Reffye arrived in good time and were received by the members of the committee, and the French and Egyptian anthems were played while Messrs. Caneri and Waast, Deputies of the French nation, received the official griests, among whom were the leading residents of all nations now in the Capital.

The theatrical performance was extremely well patronised as well as the open air dancing The display of fireworks was open to criticism and better displays have been seen on similar occasions, although, we believe, there are certain restrictions in this matter which preclude a really fine display, owing to the proximity of the houses surrounding the garden.

Where everyone, from the gasman to the President of the Committee, spared no effort to make the occasion a complete success comment would be invidious ; it is to be hoped, however, that this band of workers will be again to the fore on the next occasion and achieve as notable a success as 1907. A final tribute is due to the hospitality of the French Nation to their guests ; refreshments were good and plentiful and the Press were received with marked consideration. -

Our Suez Correspondent reports that the anniversary of the French National fête of 14th July was celebrated as usual by the Port Tewfick Club, opposite which a space was reserved for open air dancing, which was taste fully decorated with fags and profusely illuminated with electric lights. In the afternoon various amusements were indulged in, and in the evening dancing commenced in the open enclosure to the accompaniment of an excellent string band.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL POLL TAX.
div.p: In a written reply delivered last week to Mr. Henniker Heaton, who asked what number of passengers passed through the Suez Canal in the years 1876, 1886, 1896, and 1906, respectively ; what was the toll or tax paid by each person during those years ; and what would be the charges (canal dues) for a British steamer of '12,000 tons, and carrying 300 passengers, passing through to Australia, Sir E. Grey says The statistics for which the hon member asks are contained in the annual returns presented to Parliament ; the toll or tax paid by the shipowner for each passenger is 10f. per head'; assuming a tonpage register of 12,000 tons for the purpose of a Suez Canal certificate, the charge for transit on the present basis would be at 7.75c. per ton, 93,000f., or at par £3,720, and for 300 passengers at 10f., 3,000f=at par £120 ; total, £3,840. The average net tonnage per vessel passing through the canal in 1906' was however, 3,393 tons.

div.head:
CHIZEH ZOOLOGICAL GARDENS
REPORT FOR 1906.
div.p: The report on the Ghizeh Zoological Garden or 1906 by the Director, Captain Stanley . Flower, has just been issued. Each yea stablishes a new record in the numbe f visitors and the total of receipts, while ontinued progression is also registered in very direction.

During 1906, 223,425 persons visited the cardens, an increase of rathermore than 25% over 1905, and L.E. 1,706.575 mm. were taken in gate noney. The most profitable month of the year was February, when there were 32,752 visitors giving a total gate-money of L.E. 240. 625mm. und the lowest total of visitors recorded was October with 11,660 and gate money. L.E 58. 645mm. The figures for November and December give a somewhat remarkable com parison, there being 26,046 visitors during the ormer month and only 18,729 during the atter. The table of visitors for the years _899 to 1906 shows that in 1899 there were 23,567 ; 1900-44;296; 1901-50,711 ; 1902 27,117 ; 1903-55,937 ; 1904-64,711 ; 1905 - 77,587 ; and in 1906-223,425, as previously stated.
In his preface to the report the Director says :

The general bealth of the animals has beer very good; of the larger and more valuable =pecimens only one, the anaconda, died, bu on the afternoon of the 24th of April, under peculiar atmospheric conditions a severe loss was sustained, twelve monkeys and lemurs and three other mammals died suddenly withir a few minutes. Careful post-mortem examina cions, which were very kindly made by the Officials of the Government School of Medicine at Kasr el Aini, proved that death was due to leat apoplexy: the animals otherwise were in Jerfect condition.

Special attention should be called to the ollection of African ungulate animals no 31st December 1906) exhibited alive in these çardens, including : Sudanese Elephants (6) Iyraces (4, representing two species), Wilo Donkey (3), Zebras (2), Gnu (2), Hartebeest Duiker, Oribi (2), Waterbuck (3), Dorcas jazelle (17), Isabella Gazelle (2), Korin Gazelle 6), Arabian Gazelle (2), Loder's Gazelle (3) Trial (8), Ril (9), Oryx (9), Addax (3), Bush juck, Kudu (3), Sudanese Domestic Goat (3) bex (21), Domestic Sheep, (10, representing very distinct African breeds), Wild Sheer 9), Giraffe (3), Wart Hog (3), Sennar Pig (2) nd Egyptian Wild Pig.
Of the additions during 1906, which totalle :76, the following should be specially men ioned': -
Three young Drill Baboong, from Wes \frica, received in exchange from the Stell ngen Zoological Gardens, 9th July.
One very fine Hyrax, from the Peninsula o Sinai, presented by Capt. R.C.R. Owen, C.M.G. Ird June.

Three young Sudanese Elephants (two male ind one female), from the Blue Nile : purchas d: arrived in Ghizeh, 25th December. Thes ogether with the three female Elephant brought from the Blue Nile in 1905 now form i fine group of six African Elephants, a featur probably never seen before in any Zoologica Garden.
Two female Wild Donkeys: one from th province of Berber, presented by Major s Henry Hill, Bart.; and one from Goz Regebo he Atbara, presented by Mr. A. N. Wilkinson
A very fine pair of White-tailed Gnus, pu hased 9th July.
A beautiful young Northern Waterbuck, and an adult female and a young male Abyssinian Bushbuck, from Roseires, presented by Mr. L. Gorringe : arrived in Ghizeh 25th December
One Ril Antelope born in the gardens, 30th August : and five young Ril (two male and three female) from Kordofan, purchased.
One female Duiker, from Tonj, Bahr el Ghazal, presented by Capt. R. L. Moore, 6th August.
A male Loder's Gazelle presented by H.H. Prince Kamel el Din Pasha to Sir William Garstin, G.C.M.G., Adviser, P.W.D.: arrived in the Gardens 22nd February.
A particularly richly marked young male Giraffe from Kordofan ; purchased in the Sudan, arrived Ghizeh 25th December..
A Honey-Buzzard, presented by Mr. H. Raczinski of Alexandria, 7th October.
A valuable collection of Birds, received in exchange, from the Calcutta Zoological Gardens, 20th February
A tamed and healthy Boa constrictor, presented by Dr. Franz Werner of Vienna, 14th September.
An Eyed Dab-Lizard, from the province of Dongola, presented by Col. H. W. Jackson, C.B., 24th May.

The removals, which totalled 636, include ten lions sent to India, for H.H. the Maharajah of Gwalior ; thirty-five animals sent to the Stellingen Zoological Gardens, and one hundred and seven sent to the New York Zoological Society's Menagerie at Bronx Park.

The animals that disappeared during 1906 were one fox, one weasel and one lizard that escaped from their cages at night and were never seen again; one young owl and one small toad, whose disappearance can only be accounted for by the supposition that they were swallowed by their relatives in the same cages; and twenty-five small' Passerine birds which from time to time were found missing, probably having been taken by rats, or snakes, during the night.

The animals whose deaths can be directly attributed to the attacks of wild animals, include : one newly-born Ibex, one young Pheasant, one Spurwing Goose, one Parrakeet, one Love-bird, and fifty-one small Passerine birds, (mstly of the genera "Stictospiza" and "Tæniopygia," whose deaths were due to nocturnal attacks from Mice).

div.head:
THE NILE
THE RAINS AND THE FLOOD.
div.p: Captain Lyons has just compiled a ver useful and interesting work on the rains of th Nile basin and last year's food.

The series of seven dry years which begal with the exceptionally low flood of 1899 wher the volume discharged by the Nile was 37 pe cent below the average, and ended with tha of 1905 which was 35 per cent déficient, wai succeeded last year by a flood' which was more nearly of average volume.

Year by year it is possible to supplemen existing information by newer and more ample data," and to fill gaps in the chain of condition: which lead up to the summer rains of Abyssinia the feeders of the Nile flood. A few years ago the resemblance between the gauge curve of: rising flood and that of some former year wa used as the only means of anticipating it: probable development; then it was suggester that the Bombay rainfall might be utilizec as a basis of prediction, but with the re opening of the Sudan and the establishment of meteorological stations there, supplement ed by others in the equatorial regions, ou knowledge has rapidly increased, and deduc tions from accurate observations have largely replaced empirical methods. Today we cai follow the northward extension of the rain: of tropical East Africa froin Mauritius and Zomba (in British Central Africa) which lie just within the southern tropic, throng! German East Africa up to the lake plateau. Il the Seychelles Islands of the Indian Oceai and in British East Africa and Uganda, wi note them as they pass on to the Somali Coas and to the Bahr el Jebel. Further north again a chain of meteorological stations now supplie full information about the intensity and the extension of the rains from the Nile-Congo watershed through the Bahr el Ghazal, and along the Bahr el Jebel and the Sobat acros: the Sudan plains to the limits of the Monsoor region near Dongola and Berber ; to the sout! of the Abyssinian tableland information is stil meagre, and we are dependent on the journal of the few travellers who have traversed the region.

In Abyssinia itself, more systematic study of the meteorological conditions is urgently needed. When the heavy rainfall of July and August has set in, the conditions of the surrounding regions seem to give but slight indications of the variations which take place on the tableland, and as 30 per cent of the total rainfall falls in each of these months, a break in the rains lasting for 10 days may reduce the volume of the Nile flood by 10 per cent. At Addis Abbaba alone is the rainfall measured at present, and it is not yet possible to get observations from places lying further to the west, which are thus more representative of the Blue Nile basin. In 1907 a qualified meteorologist will be sent to Addis Abbaba in order to study the local conditions on the plateau during June, July, August and September.

It is also proposed to investigate the upper region of the Monsoon current over the Sudan plains by means of kites carrying self-registering apparatus, but this work which was to have been commenced in 1907 is now unavoidably postponed till 1908.

The Nile has presented several features of special interest during the past year. In both February and March, heavy rainstorms occurred in Abyssinia and the Southern Sudan, which raised the river levels and greatly improved the low stage supply of the spring months ; the steady improvement in the rainfall of August and September furnished a flood about 10 per cent below the average while the maximum gauge readings at · Wadi Halfa just exceeded the mean, a great improvement on the conditions experienced during the past seven years. We have therefore a flood of nearly normal volume to study, and our task is greatly facilitated by the new river ganges built in masonry which have been constructed by the Sudan Irrigation Service to take the place of temporary gauges.

The rains were somewhat late in reaching the Sudan plains and were at first rather .weak ; in July an improvement took place, which was maintained in August and the early part of September so that the flood on the whole was fairly satisfactory, and as guaged by the estimated volume passing Aswan, reached 0:87 of an average flood. From this it may be considered as about equal to the floods of 1900 and 1901. but coming as it did, immediately after good low-stage levels (see p. 57) and increasing to a somewhat late maximum, it may be characterized as fairly good rather than moderate only.

From May onwards, public opinion strongly inclined to the view that the flood would be an exceptionally large one, as the favourable low-stage levels, due to abnormal rainfall in February and March, were generally interpreted as the result of an early and unusual development of the sumiuer rains, but the meteorological conditions in the regions south of the Sudan never lent any support to this view, indeed, in May the prospect was distinctly unfavourable, and it was not unti after June that a decided improvement was discernible.
div.note: *The Rains of the Nile Basin and the Nile Flood of 1906, hy Captain H, G, Lyons, D.Sc., É.R.S., Director General Survey Department. Survey Department Paper No. 2, Price, 100 mil liemes, Cairo, National Printing Department, 1907.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The S.S. "Kaffir Prince," with passengers and general cargo, lett Malta on the 13th inst and is due to arrive at this port to-morrow.
The Moss liner "Amasis" sailed yesterda afternoon for London with passengers and general cargo.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: The local rank of Lewa has been conferred upon Miralai Matchett Bey, Acting Sirdar and Commandant of Khartoum district.
Paxton Bey, chief inspector of the Cairo Police returned from leave yesterday and will take the place of Mansfield Pasha during his leave.

A marriage has been arranged between Cecil Starr Mackelcan Johns, son of Mr. Edward Wildy Johns, of Osborne Lodge, Osterley Park, and Irma, only daughter of the Baron and Baroness de Kusel, of Redcliffe-square and Cairo.

The marriage arranged between Claud Den ham Gilbart Smith, of Ras-el-Tin School, Alex andria, youngest son of the late Dr. Gilbart Smith, of Harley-street, and Elena Victoria, third daughter of the late George Edward Brooking, of Dartmouth, Devon, and Pisagua, Chili, and of Mrs. Brooking, of Neville-court, will take place quietly, at St. Mary Abbot's, Kensington, on Saturday, the 20th inst. at half-past two o'clock.

The Earl of Rosslyn, against whom his second wife is seeking a divorce, after having been married to him for little more than two years, married first in 1890 Miss Violet Aline Vyner, daughter of Mr. C. de G. Vyner, but obtained a divorce from her in 1902. She then married Mr. Charles Jarrott, the motorist. In 1905 Lord Rosslyn married Anna Robinson-as she was then known—an American actress of considerable attainments.

It will be remembered that Lord Rosslyn, after a career of many vicissitudes, went on the stage and played under the name of Mr. James Erskine in "Trelawny of the Wells" at the Court Theatre. After a tour in America he went to South Africa during the war, and was captured by the Boers.

Sir William Henry Perkins, whose death is reported by Reuter's telegram, was born in March 1838, and was one of the most famous chemists of his day. He studied chemisty under the celebrated late Dr. Hofmann and was afterwards assistant in his research laboratory By his discovery of the mauve dye in 1856 he founded the coal tar industry, and his whole life was spent in scientific research in telation to chemistry. He held many scientific degrees including those of the P.R.S., LL.D., Ph. D. and D. Sc.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive left for Carlsbad yesterday by the Orient Express. His Highness is accompanied by Dr. Kantzky Bey, his private physician.

The Sultan sent his parting compliments to the Khedive through Nouri Pasha, Second Chamberlain. Amongst others at the station were General Husni Pasha, who acted as Mihmandar to his Highness, Hussein Pasha Fakhri, Egyptian Minister of Public Works, Ahmed Zeki Pasha, Master of Ceremonies,and Aziz Pasha, cousin of the Khedive.

Before entering his special carriage the Khedive requested Nouri Pasha to convey to his Imperial Majesty the expression of his gratitude for all the honours and kind attentions paid him during his stay in Constantinople.
Aziz Pasha, Ahmed Zeki Pasha and Mehmed Sadik Bey left for Alexandria yesterday by the Osmanieh, of the Khedivial Mail Line.

div.head: MARIOUT RAILWAY.
div.p: To-day the new iron bridge for the Khedives railway, which is to carry the normal gange line over the Mareotic Canal at Méx, is to be tried to see if it is quite capable of bearing the weight of trains. Three locomotives are to be put on the bridge at the same time. If the tests proves satisfactory all the trains : will run in future over this bridge, The bridge cost about £3,000. It is of French make.

div.head: OFFICIAL ENGLISH IN EGYPT.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "Egyptian GAZETTE."
Sir,-One would imagine that, since Egypt is under British Occupation, official notices in English would be etymologically correct, yet the following curiosities are to be seen in Cairo :
1st. In the Egyptian Museum, there is a notice fixed to the Hathor cow that was discovered last year at Der el Bahri, which starts as follows,

Defense to take Photographs. 2nd. Near the Zoological Gardens, the road has been altered and there is a board put up with an inscription in English, French and Arabic which commences as follows, Barred Street, the words being a literal translation of the French, whereas No Thoroughtare would have been better.
3rd. - In an advertisement that has appeared the last three years, at the railway station and in the "Egyptian Gazette," for pupils fól the Railway administration, in the following paragraph:
"A certificate of good conduct signed by the Mamour of their district and the Dadeb of their parish," parish boing to me an un known division of rural Egypt I refrain from making any comment, as
I am, Sir,

div.head: THE VIVANTE MYSTERY.
div.p: On Sunday, the police arrested' Arundsen, the ex-employé óf Vivante, and confronted him with the staff of the hotel where Vivante met his death. The staff, however, failed to recognise him and he was accordingly released.

Yesterday "Arundsen underwent a crossexamination ly the Alexandria Police at the Menshieh Caracol. He was also medically inspected by the police to see whether there were any scratches, marks, contusions and other signs about his person to show that he had been engaged in a struggle. Neither in the cross-examination nor in the medical inspection did anything come to light of a compromising character against him. :*
The mystery as to how the death was brought about remains as deep as ever.

div.head: ENGLISH COTTON MARKET.
div.p: In their bulletin of the 6th inst., Messrs. Collinge Brothers Liverpool, report that interest has been mainly centred in the "Bureau". report, which gave a "Condition" of 72, & finch lower figure than generally expected, 75 to 77 having been about the popular estimate. , ! This report showing, as it did, only 1.5% improvement on the month caused a considerable rush to bny and on all markets there has been great excitement. During the past few days however the tone has been much quieter, though the week's "futures" are abont 30 points higher.

div.head: THE BOURSE AND BANKING COMPANY OF EGYPT LIMITED..
div.p: Some local banks who have sold shares of this Company for chents intend to protest against yesterday's decision. We have received the following:
Monsieur le Directeur

de "l'Egyptián Gazette." :.. Vous avez publié dans votre numéro'd'hier le compte-rendu de l'assemblée des courtiers en valeurs d'Alexandrie, concernant te règlement des affaires traitées en Bourse and Banking (Arditi). Si j'ai bien cornpris l'artangement voté par nos agents de change, le client qui a vendu à et qui a vérsé intégralement le prix nominal de £ 1 recevra la différence entre £ 1 et son prix de venté, c'est-à-dire to de £. En d'autres termes, le capitaliste qui a 'versé £ 1 et qui gagne

par sa vente, perdra '1 de £. Odini. au contraire, qui a acheté à £ 1 ou ká-dessous et qui n'a pas vendu; quoique perdant pår son opération la différence eftre son prix d'achat et zéro (valeur actuelle de l'Arditi). se trouve ne rien perdre d'après l'arrangement voté, puisque en aucun cas la société ne délivrera les titres. Qui ne voit Pillo gisme d'un tel arrangement, aux termes duquel celui qui a gagné par son bpération est dépouillé même de ce qu'il a verse, et celui qui a perda, est dispense de tout vefigentient ! On se demandera condiment une assemblée d'agents de change the topuddeia der une chose aussi absürde. C'est bien simple. Le bon public, 18 vache lait, d'ailleurs assez genge, avenida uvedenéfice. C'est lui qui doit être dépoul116.D&utres, surpris par la crise, bont restés acheteurs défi nitifs de la plupart des actions i tot para de fondateurs. Pour ge sääver de cette inibasse, les eodrtiers et la societs ont tout simplement*** voté un petit arrangeftient que Me Merörnier1 a qualifie de loyal, honnête et salitaire.
Reste à savoir si le bon public se laissera gruger sans rien 'dire. O

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi). Aujourd'hui le marché a présenté un aspect encore plus défavorable que les jours précédents. L'affluence des vendeurs, qui ne trouvent que difficilement des contre-parties, a déterminé une nouvelle baisse partielle. Les transactions, commeon le conçoit dans de telles circonstances, sont restées clairsemées.
Les valeurs dirigeantes n'ont pas échappe à la baisse. L'Agricole revient de 7 11/16 à 7 5/8 et la National Bank de 19 5/16 à 19 15/16. La Delta Light. est cependant plus ferme à 9 5/16.

Parmi les dépréciations les plus notables i faut signaler une perte de 10 fr. sur les Dividendes Tramways à 290, de 1/4 de livre sur le Comptoir à 2 1/8 l'ancienne action et 2 la nouvelle, de P.T. 10 sur la fondateur Allotment à 50.

En baisse également l'Alexandria Water de 109/16 à 10 1/2, la Bière du Caire de 100 a 95 la Privilégiée et de 38 à 37 la Dividende les Cotton Mills de 3 à 2/6, la Salt and Soda de 16/9 à 16, l'Obligation Crédit Foncier de 310 à 309 l'ancienne et de 264 à 261 la fouvelle, les Lots Turcs de 166 à 164, la Cassa di Sconto de 32 à 30, la Delta Land de 1 7/16 à 1 5/16, l'Ordinary Khedivial Mail de 20/6 à 20 vendeurs, l'Investment de 7/16 à 3/8, le Crédit Franco-Egyptien de 4 1/8 à 4 1/16, l'action Allotment de i 15/16 à 1 7/8, la Port-Said Salt de 14/6 à 14, les Cotton Ginners de 1 3/8 à 1 1/4.
La Banque d'Athènes reprend, au contraire, de 113 à 113 1/2, et la Banque d'Orient de 114 à 114 1/2.
Le reste de la cote demeure sans changement

Demain anra lieu la vente aux enchères publiques des titres suivants : 415 Delta Land, 440 Salt and Soda, 30 Delta Light Preference, 10 Delta Light Deferred, 150 New Egyptian, 50 Daïra Sanieh, 125 Investment et 25 Com. pagnie Frigorifique.

Nous apprenons que M. Horschitz, l'un des délégués de la National Bank, prépose à la liquidation de la Cassa di Sconto, a donné sa démission, pour des raisons que l'on ignore. La National Bank a désigné à sa place M. Attilio Alessandrini, qui est très connu dans le monde financier de notre ville M, Alessandrini a dejà en l'occasion de montrer de très sérieuses qualités comme comptable et comme financier. Après avoi débuté au Crédit Lyonnais, M. Alessandrini a contribué à l'établissement à Alexandrie de la succursale du Banco di Roma.

En remplacement des membres démission naires de l'Association des Courtiers en va leurs, M.M. J. Arditi, P. Augustino et D Klat, l'Assemblée a élu hier M. J. Bekhyt par 43 voix, M. J. P. Rodocanachi par 4 voix et M. F. S. Rossano par 36 voix.

div.head: Circulaire 8. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUBS
Le Caire, Lundi 15 juillet. * Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres est

resté à 3 5/8 pour cent. Au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a haussé, vendredi passé, de 1/8 à 84 1/4 pour se maintenir à ce prix le lendemain. L'Unifiée est remontée de 1/4 à 101. La National Bank a perdu, vendredi, non moins de 5/8 à 19 1/4 pour regagner 1/8 samedi à 19 3/8. L'Agricole a rétrogradé de 1/8 à 7 3/4. La Daïra Sanieh est demeurée inchangée à 13 1/2. La Delta Light a avancé de 1/8 à 9 5/8.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien a reculé samedi de 4 francs à 680 et la Banque d'Athènes de 2 francs à 115.
Comme d'ordinaire tous les lundis, nous avons en, ce matin, un marché flasque, indécis et tant soit peu lourd, dans l'attente du vent qui soufflera cette semaine de Londres et cie Paris.

Dans le cofipartiment des Banques, la National et l'Agricole, renseignées en recul à Londres, où des ventes à terme importantes auraient été faites vendredi passé pour compte de l'Egypte, ont été ramenées presque sans affaires à 19 3,8 et 7 11/16.
La Daïra Sanieh a été mieux tenue à 13 1/8-3/16. La Béhéra a faibli à 24 3/4. L'Allotment est revenu à 1 7/8 et sa part à 57.

La Delta Light a progressé à 9 3/16-1/4. Les Jouissances Eaux du Caire ont reculé à 173-174. La Brasserie des Pyramides a fléchi à 86 et sa part à 32. Les Automobiles sont tombées à 1 9/16. Les fondateurs Héliopolis ont avancé à 9 3/4.
Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, les Egyptian se sont alourdis à 5 1/16-1/8. Les Upper Egypt ont faibli à 2 3/4 et les Ritz à 0 5/8.
Parmi les petites valeurs, la Delta Land s'est tassée à 1 9/16-5/8, les New Egyptian à 13 sh. 3, les Abdy à 07/16 et les Aboukir Land á 31 sh.
Nous détachons de notre correspondance de Londres, en date du 8 Juillet, l'intéressant passage suivant :

" Il s'est produit en fin de semaine, au Stock Exchange, de bonnes demandes en valeurs égyptiennes, . spécialement en National Bank, qui a atteint 20, et en Agricole, qui se maintient ferme à 8. Ces achats ont été faits en grande partie pour le continent et pour l'Ecosse. On commence, décidément, à se rendre un compte plus exact de l'excellence des conditions économiques générales de la vallée du Nil de l'abondante récolte du coton et du haut prix qu'on en tirera, ce qui ramènera l'or en masse dans le pays. Certes, la crise que les marchés do Caire et d'Alexandrie viennent de traverser aura des effets pendant quelques mois encore, ainsi que sa répercussion sur les autres branches de l'activité sociale. Mais c'est pousser le pessimisme à outrance que de prétendre que la contrée est ruinée pour une lon gue série d'années

"Une haute personnalité financière d'ici, dont le nom a été souvent cité ces temps derniers à propos des embarras du marché égyptien, a eu l'occasion de déclarer que l'Egypte est appelée, malgré tout, à donner lieu à des surprises encore plus agréables que celles que nous ont déjà values ses vingt premières années de développement et de prospérité.

" La conversation portait sur l'avenir des terrains, ainsi que des Sociétés qui s'en occupent. L'éminent financier dont il est question a bien reconnu que la spéculation avait imprimé, en dernier lieu, à la plus-value un essor imprudemment rapide ; mais il s'est élevé, avec raison, contre l'opinion suivant laquelle le prix du terrain en général serait appelé à suivre à l'avenir une marche décroissante. " On perd de vue, a-t-il fait remarquer en dernier ressort, que la population de l'Egypte est composée, pour plus de neuf dixièmes, d'in| digènes dont beaucoup s'enrichissent à vue

d'ail et placent leurs disponibilités uniquement en terrains, en terrains de culture aussi bien qu'en terrains de construction. L'avenir des Sociétés foncières et immobilières en Egypte n'est donc pas aussi compromis qu'on se plaît à le prétendre."
Carnet de l'actionnaire.
Le dividende de 3 shellings par action. moins l'income-tax, de l'Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Co. est payable à partir d'aujourd'hui aux guichets de la National Bank of Egypt.

Les actionnaires de la Société Egyptienne de la Bourse Commerciale de Minet-el-Bassal sont informés qu'un dividende intérimaire de 3 % (soit 12 shellings par action) est payable à partir d'aujourd'hui à l'Anglo-Egyptian Bank contre détachement du coupon No. 36.
Les recettes de la Delta Light Railways Co. pour la semaine au 6 Juillet courant se sont élevées à L.E. 4,516 contre 3,926 en 1906, soit en augmentation de L.E. 590.
Les recettes totales depuis le 1er Avril 1907 se chiffrent par L.E. 64,518 contre 52.954 pour la période correspondante de l'exercice précédent, soit en majoration de L.E. 11,564.

Les recettes des Tramways du Caire pour le mois de Juin dernier, qui clôture l'exercice 1906-07, ont été de Frs. 573,105 contre 451,947.60 pour la période correspondante de 1906, soit en plus-value de Frs. 121,157.13, ou près de 27 0/0.
L'exercice entier se termine ainsi avec un total de Frs. 6,084,663 contre 4,925,977.55 l'an dernier et 4,040,157.13 en 1904-1905.
La progression de 1905-1906 est donc de Frs. 1,158,685.45 on 23 0/0. L'augmentation de 1906-1907 sur 1904-1905 est de Francs 2,044,505.87 ou 50 1/2 pour cent.

div.head: CASINO SAN STEFANO.
div.p: · Les artistes engagés à Milan pour les con certs du Casino, sont arrivés hier par le Lloyd La direction a donc décidé de donner le premie concert, offert aux abonnés, demain soir 9 h. 3/4 dans la salle des fêtes. Ces artiste seront accompagnés par le grand orchestra Bracale
Messieurs les abonnés qui par erreur ni devraient pas recevoir de carte d'invitation sont priés de bien vouloir la réclamer au secré tariat du Casino.
Pour les non abonnés le prix sera de P.T. 20

A great demonstration was held yesterday in Trafalgar Square to protest against any "entente" with Russia, whose regime was bitterly denounced. Subsequently, the crowd, led by Mr. Thorne, M.P., the Socialist Mr. Hyndman, and others, marched to the Foreign Office. The police dispersed them after half an hour's desperate scrummaging. Several persons were badly bruised, including Mistress Despard.
(Reuter)

div.head:
ENGLAND AND GERMANY.
COMBINED NAVAL REVIEW.

div.p: Prince Henry of Prussia's squadron is on its way here to meet the British cruiser squadron.
It is believed that the Emperor, who is now n's here yatching, will review the combined fleet.
(Reuter)

div.head:
THE BRITISH FLEET.
MISHAP TO DESTROYER.

div.p: The destroyer "Lee" has arrived at Plymouth with her side badly stove in in a collision with the Dutch cruiser "Friesland." (Reuter)

STEPS FOR RELEASE.

(Reuter)

AMERICAN EMBASSY IN DANGER.

EGYPTIAN STUDENTS IN FRANCE.

div.p: Egyptian and French students celebrated the anniversary of the Khedive's birthday. Cordial toasts were exchanged. (Havas)
The crniser "Cambrian" has landed a force in the New Hebrides to avenge the murder of a European by natives. A bluejacket has been killed and another, wounded. (Reuter)

Baron Aehrenthal, accompanied by the Austrian Ambassador in Italy, arrived yesterday at Signor Tittoni's residence in Desio (Lambardy). The two Ministers will go on Tuesday to Racconigi where they will lunch with the King and Queen. Signor Tittoni will return Baron Behrenthal's visit at Semmering on 14th August. Both of them will visit the Emperor at Ischl on the following day.(Reuter)
Baron Aehrental and Signor Tittoni were in conference for two hours. (Reuter)
Several Sovereigns have telegraphed the | congratulations to M. Fallières. The Ambassa sdors signed the visitors' book at the Elysée.

div.head: THE TYRANNY OF LONDON.
div.p: "People who write from London about London for the provinces very frequently speak of 'London opinion,' saying that the 'London opinion' on such-and-such is so-and-so; but they rarely state in what way they get 'London opinion,'" says the "Edinburgh Evening News,"

"An entertaining and suggestive article on 'The Tyranny of London' is contributed to the "Referee" by Mr. Sydney Brooks, a jonrnalist from America...... He remarks that London is not only the biggest capital in the world, bnt the most comprehensive. 'London,' writes Mr. Brooks, 'not only dominates England, but overpowers it-in a measure devitalises it.' He adds that no other capital, with the doubtfal exception of Paris, absorbs so much of the national life around it. Berlin is not to Germany, Rome is not to Italy, Vienna is not to Austria, still less is Madrid to Spain, all that London is to England-by which, presumably, Mr. Brooks means Great Britain.

"While admitting the extent to which London dominates the rest of the land, Mr. Brooks says that there is one sphere beyond the influence of its absorbent magnetism, the sphere of politics. 'Except,' he writes; 'at brief moments of intense national excitement, London has never had the same political power as Paris. For one thing, provincial and local life and government are far too highly developed among us to permit of the centralised ascendancy of anyone city. For another, London is altogether too languid, too social, and too sociable to be a keen politician. There is no city in which it is so hard to start a 'movement.' Its political opinions nine times out of ten are the opinions of clubland and the West End,

"No doubt there is much truth in this—and the great political movements of recent years did not have their origin here. At the same time innumerable movements have begun here, as Mr. Brooks may be willing to admit. Take such movements as Æstheticism, Anti-Vaccination, Votes for Women, Bernard-Shawism, Rodinism, Archeritis, the Society of Twelve, and Tubes-all these things had their birth in London, and of some of them London is very proud indeed. ... Mr. Brooks proceeds that the city is at once too big and too much de. pendent on society to have either the concentration or the energy necessary for political leadership, adding that even to its own affairs it is magnificently indifferent. 'It has no civic consciousness' he says, for sense of a corporate life or local pride'. ...

"Mr. Brook expresses wonder as to whether or not it is a good thing for a country to be ruled by so overwhelming a capital as we. possess in London. He wants to know if the domination of a Paris or a London is a real or only a seeming advantage. He asks :

Does a nation fare better or worse when it escapes the toll which such huge agglomerations exact on the social health, the intellectual alertness, and the politicat virility of the people? : . . Washington is a capital by prenatal malice aforethought; it was to be the capital that it was called into existence. And within the last year or two history has repeated itself in the Antipodes with curious carefulness. The same fears and jealousies that moved Americans over a century ago to fix the seat of the Federal Government on a stretch of marshy woodland, far away from the real life of the nation, have all been stirring the Australian democracy; and the rivalries of the States, and especially of the big cities like Melbourne and Sydney, have finally cast the Australian capital of the future into the outer solitudes.

"Having so delivered himself, Mr. Brooks has a statement that will not easily pass muster without range of Bow Bells, which is that the talents of the kingdom are so concentrated on London that England (meaning Britain, no doubt, Mr. Brooks ?) as a whole is left comparatively depleted and stagnant.'"

div.head: THE GOVERNOR OF THE LEBANON
div.p: The latest issue to hand of the " Levant Herald" gives the following details about the mew Governor of the Lebanon:

We have much pleasure in announcing that H.E. Youssouf Bey Coussa. "Chef de Cabinet" of the Ministry for Foreign Affairs, has been named Governor of the Lebanon in succession to the late Marshal Muzzafer Pasha. His Excellency has at the same time been promoted to the rank of Vizier which bears with it the title of Pasha.
We understand that his Excellency and Mme Youssouf Pasha will leave for Beirut in the course of next week.

Youssouf Pasha Franco is the son of the late Franco Pasha, who was also at one time Governor of the Lebanon. He was born in Constantinople in 1856 and entered the service of the Imperial Government at the age of 17. He was first attached to the secretariat of the Ministry for Foreign Affairs and obtained rapid promotion in that Department. In 1900 he was named "Chef de Cabinet" of the Minister. He acted as secretary to the Ottoman Delegation at the first Peace Conference. | Youssouf Pasha Franco has throughout | his career at the Ministry for Foreign Affairs displayed diplomatic abilities of the highest order, and he is a persona gratissima both in Ottoman official circles and in the Diplo| matic Body. No better choice could have been made for the important office his Excellency is now called upon to fill, and we beg to join in the numerous congratulations he has already received on his new appointment.
Youssouf Pasha possesses mapy Ottoman and Foreign Orders and amongst others the Grand : Cordons of the Osmanieh and the Medjidieh and the medals of the Imtiaz and the Liakat

div.head: EGYPTIAN TEMPLES.
div.p: EXHIBITION AT KING'S COLLEGE.

The exhibition of the results of the season's work by the Egypt Exploration Fund, which opened last week at King's College, is one of more than usual interest. It represents the finish of one of the greatest works of archæolo gical exploration ever undertaken by an English society. More than fourteen years ago the fund commenced its work of clearing the great temple on the face of the cliffs at Deir el Bahari, near Thebes. This immense edifice, | built by the great Queen Hatshepsu, was one of the wonders of Egypt, differing in style from all other temples, and, especially from the | temples of Thebes. The work entailed not merely the exploration of the temple, but also, as far as possible, a restoration of the edifice by restoring the fallen or broken pieces to their positions, and the removal of Coptic and other buildings which had been built within the temple.

All visitors to Egypt are familiar with this beautiful edifice, rising as it does terrace above terrace from the plain to the face of the cliff. The festival hall, the curious birth chamber, the corridor with sculptures representing the naval expedition to the incense land of Persil, now called Somaliland, have all been cleared and restored as far as possible. This work occupied about ten years, and was carried out by Professor Neville, assisted by Mr. Howard Carter. The large temple belonged to the eighteenth dynasty, B.C. 1800. In clearing away the apparent rubbish heaps on the south side of the enclosure, an astonishing find was made of a beautiful funeral temple of Mentuhetys, of the eleventh dynasty. Four Seasons have been devoted to the exploration of this beautiful temple, and the work is now complete, having occupied about fourteen years at an average expenditure of about £1,000 a year. It is from this temple that the objects now exhibited come.

THE TOMB OF THE KING. The whole of the edifice was grouped round a central pyramid which marked the tomb of the King. The chief object of this year's work was to find this tomb. After much labour a sloping passage, 600ft. long, was found under the platform, but it was impossible to enter the chamber this way as the huge blocks of sandstone forming the roof had fallen. It was then resolved to dig a side passage into the tomb chamber, and at last entrance was obtained. But tomb robbers had been there before. There are here exhibited many objects of interest-funeral boats, little models of groups of servants, bows, arrows, and staffs of office, which had been in many cases stripped. of their gold plating. One very fine boat with a double line of oars is exhibited. In the centre of the tomb was a great shrine, over 12ft. high and 10ft. wide, constructed of translucent alabaster, but it was too heavy to move.

By far the most attractive portion of this exhibition will be the beautiful painted sculptures in a style peculiar to the period, and probably the work of Mertisen, who was the Court artist and sculptor of that day, The portraits of the King and his queens, especially the Queen Aashait, exhited on Table B, have a delicacy of workmanship that is most astonishing. The coloured hieroglyphics are really miniature works of art. The procession of princesses is a beautiful piece of drawing. Especially t be noticed are the painted scenes

from the Chapel of the Princess Kemsit, pro- bably a negress. This work of art and the mummy of the lady will be fouud later in the British Museum. Students of art should notice the hunting scenes and the fine drawing of birds. There is only one warlike scene, and that appears to represent a war against the people of Sinai.

THE SMALLER EXHIBITS. In the clearing up many sinall objects of great interest were found, such as workmen's tools, hammers, nails, chisels, and paint brushes. The display of the beautiful blue glazed ware, used especially as votive offerings to Hathor, the goddess of the turquoise land, is very fine. The textile work is also good, including painted pieces of linen with figures of a whole family, and especially rare are the pieces of linen with beads interwoven, not sewn on. Mention of some curious pilgrim "ex votos" must be made. These are tracings 1 of men's sandals, with their names scratched l in the middle. If the exhibition is somewhat mixed, it represents the completion of a great work. Next season the fund will undertake Tavtensive work at Abydos.

div.head:
EGYPT'S FINANCIAL CRISIS.
ODE TO THE CROAKERS.
div.p: AFTER HOOD.
O, saw ye not the rises,
When things were at their best? Ye grumble now the shares are down;
And wear a look distress'd ; Ye walk about like spectres,
In solemn sackcloth dress'd, With faces long as violins,
Because ye can't invest. And yet there'll be more rises
Ere p'ra'ps another night; The present gloom will pass away,
And things once more be bright. And happy will the buyer be
That knows not any fright. But with his bargain simply waits
Until the Boom's in sight, And ye who long for rises,
Yet cannot buy for fear, May never know the moment now
A big Boom may be here ! While ye may think it far away,
It may be very near ; And shares that now are very cheap
Will then be very dear, 0, saw ye not the rises
Those shares have had before. -When hour by hour to giddy heights
They all began to Roar ! When all day long, and every day,
The profits were galore ; It wonld have been a glorious dream
If it had been no more! There must, there will be rises,
And rises by the score, As good as any that have gone
At any time before. Alas that creakers there should be,
Who present days deplore, And say that we shall never see Improvement any moro!
("The Daily Report.")

div.head: ROWING. CAPTAIN DARELLS VICTORY.
div.p: The victory at Henley of Captain Darell, who belongs to the Army of Occupation at Cairo, has around considerable interest among that officer's many friends in Egypt. Mr. Aug. Nickolls comments on the feat in the following words:

The Diamond Sculls provided some excellent racing. The heat between the veteran Blackstaffe and Captain Darell, won by the latter by half a length, was a real treat, honours being almost equally divided. It was also good to see the Guardsman scull Herr Barnhard von Gaza to a standstill a quarter of a mile from the finish in the ante-fipal. MacCulloch, the Oxford freshman, was badly boated, and he won an unsatisfactory race against R. V. Powell, who stopped for him when he took a pile at the end of 70 seconds' sculling. The Henley Regatta Committee should make a strict rule that ne boat should be allowed to wait for an opponent who steers off the course. After all, bad steering should be just as much a disqualification for victory as bad sculling. If a man stops when his adversary makes a mistake he is naturally called a good sportsman, but after all why should he wait, especially if he has other races to row or scull ? Captain Darell is a very much improved sculler; he stays well and goes fast. His victory was well deserved, and the ordinary layman does not fully realise what a Guardsman has to give up in order to train for the Diamonds. MacCulloch sculled well, and he has time and youth in his favour ; he is a natural waterman, but has got to learn how to row himself ont. With careful training and coaching and a strengthening op of his will power the highest honours are easily within his grasp.

Le cautionnement est fixé à LE. 15.
Le cahier des charges est déposé an Bureau de la Voirie où il peut-être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 18 courant.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation la même jour à 5h.p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: "Soumission pour les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs."

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 18 courant à midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée.
L'Administrateur.
(signé) W.P. Chataway.
Alexandrie, le 7 juillet 1905.
